definition: the New Culture Movement (mid-1910s and 1920s), intellectual revolution against Confucianism aiming to introduce Western elements, especially democracy and science
abbr. for Xinjiang 新疆[Xin1 jiang1] or Singapore 新加坡[Xin1 jia1 po1]/surname Xin
to make into/to change into/-ization/to ... -ize/to transform/abbr. for 化學|化学[hua4 xue2]
(of sth) to move/to set in movement/to displace/to touch/to make use of/to stir (emotions)/to alter/abbr. for 動詞|动词[dong4 ci2], verb

sentences.english: And the change of value directly leaded the rise of "new culture movement".
sentences.chinese: 而這種價值觀念的變革直接導致了新文化運動的興起。

sentences.english: The new cultural movement was to aimed at the national salvation.
sentences.chinese: 民族救亡是新文化運動的目的。

sentences.english: This paper attempts to analyse the split reason from the position of Hushi for New Culture Movement.
sentences.chinese: 本文從胡適對新文化運動的主張試分析其分裂的原因。

sentences.english: This book is a monumental work worthy of China's new cultural movement.
sentences.chinese: 這部著作不愧爲中國新文化運動的豐碑。

definition: May Fourth Movement/Chinese national renewal movement that started with 4th May 1919 protest against the Treaty of Versailles
Self-Strengthening Movement (period of reforms in China c 1861-1894), also named 自強運動|自强运动
Chen Yun (1905-1995), communist leader and economist
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Joseph Needham (1900-1995), British biochemist and author of Science and Civilization in China
to work part time while studying/work-study program
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Yanjing or Yenching University, Christian university in Beijing founded in 1919
